text: Nostalgia is a quaint word, one that summons visions of things that are toasty, comfy, wholesome, reassuring — all qualities, as it happens, that we associate with the 1964 Walt Disney nanny - from - heaven musical “ Mary Poppins. ” Yet nostalgia can also be a magical thing. It ’ s the great time machine of human emotion, with the power to turn the past into the present, the present into the past, and time itself into something timeless. “ Mary Poppins Returns, ” a sequel set 30 years after the first film, isn ’ t the immortal children ’ s movie that the singular, luminous, slightly screw - loose Disney original was. Yet it ’ s a rapturous piece of nostalgia — a film that devotes
